dc:title: Pollination ecology of a forest-dominant palm (Orbignya phalerata Mart.) in northern Brazil
dc:creator: Anderson A.
dc:description: Inflorescences are either morphologically staminate or androgynous. In a functional sense the former are invariably male and the latter generally female. Individual trees vary from exclusively staminate to predominantly androgynous. Flowering peaked in the rainy season (January-May). The only likely insect pollinator is the nitidulid beetle Mystrops mexicana. This species occurs in abundance on both flower types. Wind pollination also occurs, more common in such relativley open sites as pastures. The combination of 2 pollination syndromes enhances this species' adaptability to a wide range of habitats. -from Authors

dc:title: Deforestation rates and trends in Costa Rica, 1940 to 1983
dc:creator: Sader S.A.
dc:description: Deforestation occurred predominantly in tropical dry and moist life zones during the early reference periods; in intermediate periods, tropical and premontane moist and wet zones were affected. By 1983, only the less accessible high-rainfall zones in rugged terrain retained relatively undisturbed forest. The relationship between total primary forest cleared and slope gradient began as inverse and did not approach linearity until the last reference period, when improved transportation routes had penetrated the NE lowland Atlantic region. Road development that provided access to the forest was an important agent of change in all periods. -from Authors

dc:title: Predators of fig wasps
dc:creator: Bronstein J.
dc:description: Predators inflict high mortality on the 4 species of wasps associated with the fig Ficus pertusa in Monteverde, Costa Rica. One of these wasps is the obligated pollinator of the fig. The natural histories of several predators are described: an ant that feeds on wasps arriving to oviposit, moth and weevil larvae that destroy wasps as they develop within the fruits, a staphylinid beetle that feeds on mature wasps before they leave the fruits, and a group of birds that gleans wasps as they leave. The synchrony of arrival and departure of pollinators from the fig trees probably make them the species least vulnerable to predation. -from Author

dc:title: Zooplankton abundance in the Caura River, Venezuela
dc:creator: Saunders J.
dc:description: Some 72 species were recorded, of which 10 accounted for >90% of individuals. Copepods were represented almost exclusively by cyclopoid nauplii. Most cladocerans were from planktonic genera; Bosminopsis was the most abundant. The rotifer faunas was dominated by the planktonic genera Filinia, Keratella Conochilus and Polyarthra; Lecane, a littoral genus, was also common, especially at low water. Mean density of Crustacea was 2.4 organisms l-1 and the mean of Rotifera was 5.4 l-1. The annual export of zooplankton biomass from the 47 500 km2 watershed was 39 270 kg C. As the river rises early in the wet season and inundates the floodplain, zooplankton densities increase sharply. At peak discharge, densities fall to very low levels. Near the end of the wet season as the river recedes, floodplain lakes drain into the river and zooplankton abundance reaches the annual maximum. Abundance declines when the connection between river and floodplain disappears. There are also small pulses of abundance at minimum flow, chiefly of organisms washed in from channel refuges in response to short-term fluctuations in river level. Reproduction is generally insignificant in the river. Virtually all organisms in the river are swept in from refuges in the channel or the floodplain of the Caura and its lower tributaries. Zooplankton density in the river is thus regulated by flow regime, not by biological mechanisms. -from Authors

dc:title: Decimations, extinctions, and colonizations of frog populations in southeast Brazil and their evolutionary implications
dc:creator: Heyer W.R.
dc:description: Analysis of a 35yr data base suggests 3 kinds of species changes: appearance of Hyla albopunctata at Boraceia; possible extinction of Fritziana ohausi at Boraceia when the bamboo species in which Fritziana reproduces flowered and died; and population reductions and extinctions of a number of species at several localities in SE Brazil in 1979, most likely due to unusually heavy frosts. -from Authors

dc:title: Nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur properties of some forest soils on Barro Colorado Island, Panama
dc:creator: Yavitt J.
dc:description: The striking consistency in the patterns of net mineralization among the eight soils was unexpected because of differences in the total element contents of the soils and in the parent materials, vegetation on the site, and history of disturbance to the vegetation. -from Authors

dc:title: Changes with leaf age in stomatal function and water status of several tropical tree species
dc:creator: Reich P.
dc:description: Changes with leaf age in diffusive resistance (r1) and xylem pressure potential (Pp were monitored in leaves of five tropical tree species. In all species, very young, expanding leaves had high r1 and Pp in situ and wilted soon after being excised. Among fully expanded leaves, stomatal control declined with increasing age, especially in the deciduous species. In Tabebuia rosea, intact older leaves had lower r1 and greater water deficits than younger leaves. In T. rosea and Cordia glabra, excised older leaves had higher transpiration rates and wilted sooner than younger leaves. Also, old T. rosea (but not C. glabra) leaves had lower r1 at night than younger leaves. In Licania arborea, Anacardium excelsium and Mangifera indica, intact older leaves had higher r1 and a smaller range of r1 than younger leaves and displayed less stomatal closure following excision. M. indica and L. arborea leaves had the most sensitive stomatal response and the best control of water loss, even when detached; these species remained evergreen and continued to grow even during seasonal drought. Stomatal control of water loss was poorest in T. rosea, which is leafless 4-6 months each year. -from Authors

dc:title: Relative abundance of day-flying insects in treefall gaps vs shaded understory in a Neotropical forest
dc:creator: Shelly T.
dc:description: Insects were sampled within semideciduous, lowland forest of Barro Colorado Island, Panama, from April (late dry season) to August (mid wet season). For most taxa, numbers of individuals captured were relatively low during the first sampling period (prior to onset of heavy rains), increased to peak levels between mid-May and mid-June, then declined slightly in July and August. Statistically significant differences in abundance between gap and understorey sites were noted only for Formicidae, Coleoptera and Psocoptera. In all 3 cases, greater numbers of individuals were trapped at understory sites. Size frequency distributions were similar between treefall gaps and understory for all taxa. -from Author

dc:title: Litter decomposition in a lowland rain forest and a deforested area in Sri Lanka
dc:creator: Maheswaran J.
dc:description: Cullenia ceylanica (Bombacaceae) leaf litter was reduced by 63% in one year in forest vs 41.7% in fernland, whereas Dicranopteris linearis (Gleicheniaceae) frond litter was reduced by 24.6% in the forest vs 15.7% in the fernland. A positive correlation with amount of rainfall was observed for the mass loss of C. ceylanica litter in both sites; litter of D. linearis showed no such correlation. Nutrient changes indicated immobilization of N in both litter types in both sites and that of P only in D. linearis. Concentration and mass of K, Mg and Ca decreased with decomposition in all experimental treatments. A relatively slow rate of decomposition and an accumulation of organic matter in the fernland contribute to the conservation of nutrients in this aggrading ecosystem. -from Authors

dc:title: On the distribution of Greater Antillean bats
dc:creator: Griffiths T.
dc:description: Identifies 2 overall distribution patterns in Greater Antillean bats. 1) Found among most of the earliest known bat colonizers of the Antilles, Cuban and Hispaniolan bats have a close taxonomic relationship, whereas Jamaican and Puerto Rican bats are more distantly related. This pattern supports a limited vicariance model for early Antillean colonizers, or possibly a dispersal model modified to take into account mid-Tertiary geography. 2) Found among more recent bat colonizers, species accumulate in the western Antillean islands of Cuba and Jamaica, with limited dispersal eastward. The 2nd pattern supports a dispersal model modified to take into account Pleistocene climatic cycles. -from Authors

dc:title: Thermal relations of some tropical frogs along an altitudinal gradient
dc:creator: Christian K.
dc:description: Temperate-zone amphibians generally show an acclimation response of tolerance to high temperatures (CTMax). The Puerto Rican frog Eleutherodactylus portoricensis failed to show an acclimation response, but did show a negative correlation between elevation and CTMax. Subsequently, E. portoricensis, as originally understood, was found to consist of a widespread species (Eleutherodactylus coqui) and a species restricted to high elevations (E. portoricensis). CTMax was determined for these 2 species. Differences previously believed to be attributable to elevation are, in fact, interspecific differences. There were no differences in CTMax of E. coqui from different elevations, but E. portoricensis had significantly lower CTMax. E. coqui failed to show an acclimation response. The few species of tropical amphibians that have been investigated suggest that, unlike most temperate-zone species, some tropical species fail to show an acclimation response, and some fail to show a negative correlation between CTMax and elevation. -from Authors

dc:title: Phylogeny and distribution of Luffa (Cucurbitaceae)
dc:creator: Heiser C.
dc:description: The genus Luffa comprises 5 species of tropical vines, 4 native to the Old World and L. operculata to the New World. L. aegyptiaca and L. acutangula include domesticated plants that are now widespread in the tropics. L. graveolens, or more likely a species ancestral to it and L. operculata, gave rise to L. operculata. Luffa presents several disjunct distributions. -from Authors

dc:title: Seed bank dynamics and germination ecology in Espeletia timotensis (Compositae), an Andean giant rosette
dc:creator: Guariguata M.
dc:description: Espeletia timotensis was studied from the Venezuelan Andes (Paramo) at 4200 m elevation. After 1 yr (coinciding with the end of the rainy season) 55% of seeds remained viable, 17% had germinated, and mortality accounted for 30%. Soil samples collected at the beginning and the end of the rainy season and sieved to separate buried seeds revealed naturally occurring viable seeds on both occasions. In the laboratory, maximum germination percentages were 80 and 67% in light and darkness, respectively, much higher than the germination percentage observed in the field. -from Authors

dc:title: Changing sexual expression of a Brazilian rain forest palm (Attalea funifera Mart.)
dc:creator: Voeks R.
dc:description: Piassava changes sexual function during its life cycle, from male under various conditions to increasingly female as it becomes taller and less crowded. The cost of reproducing through female as opposed to male function is 13.2 to 1. Allocation of resources to reproduction increases with size. Varying access to sunlight in the rain forest environment may set thresholds to gender expression. Thus, with its low reproductive budget, piassava initially reproduces as a male in the understory. As it grows and enters the energy-rich canopy, piassava increases its reproductive budget, the cost restraints on fruit production are relaxed, and female function can be realized. -from Author

dc:title: Effects of "selective' timber extraction on rain forest structure and composition and some consequences for frugivores and folivores
dc:creator: Johns A.
dc:description: In a W Malaysian dipterocarp forest in Pahang, extracting 3.3% of trees actually destroyed 50.9%. Damage was spread equally among all tree taxa and all size classes. The overall availability of food sources for frugivores and folivores is thus drastically reduced, even where timber trees are not themselves used by animals. To some extent, initial loss of food sources may be buffered by increased reproductive and vegetative activity of those trees that remain. -from Author

dc:title: Soil-eating by red leaf monkeys (Presbytis rubicunda) in Sabah, Northern Borneo
dc:creator: Davies A.
dc:description: The main items in the animals' annual diet were young leaves, seeds, whole fruits and flowers. Large, dry seeds made up ↔85% of the diet in 2 months, but young leaves, fruits, and flowers were generally eaten when large seeds were unavailable. Soil eating was observed on 9 occasions. The soil was always collected by breaking lumps off termitaria and never from the forest floor. Termitaria soil was of higher pH and had higher levels of the main cationic nutrients and lower levels of labile aluminium. The geophagy was noted when the dietary items were highly digestible and contained few tannins, ie geophagy need not be primarily for tannin absorption, although it might have helped to absorb toxins. The main benefits are more likely to be the alleviation of digestive disorders, and supplementation of mineral nutrient uptake in a generally oligotrophic environment. There is no reason why geophagy should have a single function. -from Authors

dc:title: Does the correlation of elevation with plant taxonomic richness vary with latitude?
dc:creator: Smith A.
dc:description: Elevation may be a better predictor of generic richness in the tropics than in the temperate zone: elevation accounted for a greater proportion of variation in generic richness in the tropics (higher partial r2), and a given increase in elevation was associated with a greater increase in generic richness in the tropics than in the temperate zone (steeper slope of the regression line). Stepwise multiple regressions suggest that only area and elevation were significantly correlated with generic richness in the tropics, together accounting for 73% of total island-to-island variations; only elevation and distance to mainland were significant for the temperate sites, together accounting for 28% of island-to-island variation. -from Author

dc:title: Wing coloration of free-flying neotropical butterflies as a signal learned by a specialized avian predator
dc:creator: Chai P.
dc:description: Hamadryas feronia and H. amphinome closely resemble each other in behavior, morphology and upperside wing pattern, but differ in underside wing pattern: that of the former is mostly white, whereas that of the latter is mostly orange-red. H. feronia is palatable; a caged male rufous-tailed jacamar Galbula ruficauda always attacked and ate it in feeding trials. H. amphinome is unpalatable, and although it was sometimes attacked by the bird, it was always rejected after tasting. Most individuals of H. feronia, whose white underside wing area was painted orange, were ignored or taste-rejected by the jacamar. Thus, he responded to them as if they were H. amphinome. Similar trials were performed with 7 species of butterflies known to be palatable to the jacamar. In addition to changing the color of the butterflies, paint rendered them distasteful. After ingesting painted butterflies, the bird vomited, and tended to reject similarly painted individuals afterwards. Butterflies painted with black, orange, and red - colors generally associated with local unpalatable butterflies - were rejected more frequently than were those painted with green, blue, yellow, and brown - colors generally associated with local palatable butterflies. Individuals of naturally bright or light-colored butterfly species, on which the painted colors were better expressed, were rejected more consistently by the jacamar than were those of dull or dark-colored species. -from Author

dc:title: Gap dynamics of a tropical cloud forest in northeastern Mexico
dc:creator: Arriaga L.
dc:description: In Tamaulipas species producing gaps are those dominating the canopy layer in c80% of treefalls. An average of 19 patches ha-1 was registered, comprising 25% of the study site. Mean patch size as fitted to a lognormal distribution was 4.71±0.6. Turnover rates were 158 yr for areas disturbed by natural causes and 90 yr for areas disturbed by natural plus man-induced causes. The natural and actual gap production rates were 0.5 and 0.63 gap ha-1yr-1, ie an average of 1.27% of the forest area is disturbed every year by natural causes, 2.22% of the area by joint causes. -from Author

dc:title: Breeding biology and diet of red-tailed hawks in Puerto Rico
dc:creator: Santana C. E.
dc:description: Buteo jamaicensis jamaicensis territories in dry and moist lowland sites were dominated by pastures; those in montane rain forest and cloud forest were dominated by closed-canopy forests. Populations in rain and cloud forests lived at higher densities, but had a lower reproductive success. Frequent rain and fog reduced flying time of adults and reduced prey delivery rates at rain and cloud forest nests, increasing nestling mortality. Peak fledging occurred at the beginning of the rainy season and coincided with peak abundance of prey species. Diet of lowland hawks was mostly of mammals; that of hawks in rain and cloud forests was mostly of birds, reptiles and amphibians captured in the canopy. The breeding season in Puerto Rico extended from November-August and lasted longer than those reported for other populations of red-tailed hawks. Clutch size and incubation and nestling periods were similar to those reported for continental North America, but fledglings remained in their parents' territories for more prolonged periods in Puerto Rico. -from Authors

dc:title: Association of birds with monkeys in Costa Rica
dc:creator: Boinski S.
dc:description: Double-toothed kite Harpagus bidentatus, gray-headed tanager Eucometis pencillata and tawny-winged woodcreeper Dendrocincla anabatina forage in association with squirrel monkey Saimiri oerstedi troops in Parque Nacional Corcovado throughout the year. These species and other occasional attendants fed on arthropods and small vertebrates flushed by the monkeys. Kits, tanagers and woodcreepers spent roughly twice as much time following squirrel monkeys during the wet season, when arthropod availability was lowest, as at other times of the year. Bird attendance frequency was greatest in the morning during the wet season, but time of day differences were less distinctive in other seasons. Kites also followed capuchin monkeys Cebus capucinus, but appeared to prefer squirrel monkeys. -from Authors

dc:title: Inexpensive coulometers for integration of sensor output: measurement of solar radiation
dc:creator: Benzing D.H.
dc:description: The expert measurement of sunlight on plants requires expensive instrumentation and considerable knowledge of physics, as can be seen in recent editions of Agricultural and Forest Meteorology. Nevertheless, it seemed that a simpler system could be devised that would yield data within, for example, 10 percent of state-of-the-art accuracy at a fraction of the cost. This note describes such a method, specifically designed to monitoring photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) in multiple tropical forest sites over periods of days or weeks. Of particular interest were habitats occupied by epiphytes in remote areas where the weight and bulk of instrumentation and its susceptibility to damage pose serious problems. -from Authors

dc:title: Wounds on the yellow-bellied sea snake (Pelamis platurus) from Panama: evidence of would-be predators?
dc:creator: Weldon P.
dc:description: Discusses mid-body wounds on P. platurus, and reports on the reactions of bullseye puffer Sphoeroides annulatus (a suspected predator of these snakes) to live P. platurus and to pieces of these snakes and other animals presented during feeding tests. -from Authors

dc:title: Foraging decisions during nectar feeding by tamarin monkeys (Saguinus mystax and Saguinus fuscicollis, Callitrichidae, Primates) in Amazonian Peru
dc:creator: Garber P.A.
dc:description: For moustached and saddleback tamarin monkeys, throughout most of the year, insects, fruits and plant exudates are the primary components of the diet. However, during the dry season months of July and August, nectar from Symphonia globulifera (Guttiferae) accounted for 22-31% of tamarin feeding time. These primates are highly destructive in their nectar-feeding activities: a single adult tamarin may destroy 6-14 Symphonia flowers per feeding minute. Foraging activities associated with nectar feeding are reminiscent of traplining behavior and characterized by goal-directed travel to particular feeding trees. S. mystax and S. fuscicollis appear to be aware of the distribution and location of flowering Symphonia trees in their home range and select nectar sites largely on the basis of proximity. Expectations regarding amount and variance of the food reward were also important in tamarin foraging decisions. By minimizing random foraging movements and bypassing trees with limited food rewards, these small-bodied primates can exploit widely scattered but predictable resources. -from Author

dc:title: The influence of aggressive ants on fruit removal in the tropical tree, Ficus capensis (Moraceae)
dc:creator: Thomas D.W.
dc:description: Examined the effect of aggressive arboreal weaver ants Oecophylla longinoda on dispersal of fruits from the West African fig Ficus capensis. Compared with trees having no or few O. longinoda, trees with large ant colonies had reduced levels of nocturnal fruit removal and an increased proportion of fruits that fell undispersed. Diurnal fruit removal did not differ significantly between trees with different densities of ants. This shift in fruit dispersal characteristics resulted from the clustering of aggressive O. longinoda on the fruiting rama at night. Although ant-plant mutualisms are commonly thought to have evolved from the enhanced fitness that aggressive ants confer on occupied trees by reducing herbivory or competition, reduced seed dispersal in zoochoric species may be an important evolutionary block. -Author

dc:title: Impacts of the 1982-1983 El Nino on population dynamics of Andean condors in Peru
dc:creator: Wallace M.
dc:description: For at least 4yr prior to the 1982-1983 El Nino, nearly all adult Vultur gryphus in a coastal population and an Andean foothill population refrained from breeding, whereas condors in a high-elevation population appeared to be breeding once every other year. The severe environmental disruptions of the El Nino caused the food supply for the coastal population of condors to decrease, while the food supply for the foothill population increased 17-fold. In response to the increase in food, almost all condors in the foothill population bred in the months following El Nino. No condors in the coastal population bred after El Nino, and breeding of condors in the high-elevation population was presumably unaffected. If they can reproduce only during the unpredictable El Nino years, coastal and foothill condor populations may barely be able to maintain their numbers without ingress from more regularly breeding populations. The rate of breeding in these desert-dwelling condors seems to be the lowest recorded among birds. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecology of the pelagic fishes of Lake Titicaca, Peru-Bolivia
dc:creator: Vaux P.
dc:description: Gill nets set at 3 depths at an open-water station during August 1984 captured only 2 species of endemic killifishes (Orestias ispi, O. mulleri) and an exotic silverside (Basilichthyes bonariensis). These species segregated strongly by depth, with B. bonariensis and O. mulleri occurring only in the surface and bottom sets, respectively, and O. ispi being most abundant in the mid-water set. All species were feeding on zooplankton, but O. mulleri also ate benthic crustaceans. Copepods were strongly selected by large (>200 mm SL) B. bonariensis; whereas smaller size classes ate mainly cladocerans. Copepods and cladocerans were about equally represented in the average diet of adult O. ispi, but larvae contained only copepods. Both Orestias species are probably fractional spawners. Horizontal trawls, made at depth between 10 m and the bottom, collected mainly Orestias larvae. -from Authors

dc:title: Australian rock-mammals: a phenomenon of the seasonally dry tropics
dc:creator: Freeland W.J.
dc:description: Mammal species specializing on rocky habitats constitute 11% of Australia's marsupial and rodent species. Most rock-dwelling species are limited to the seasonally dry tropics. These habitats experience a single wet season followed by a long dry season. Runoff from rocky escarpments, water absorption by large rock formations, and the presence of aquifers in rock result in greater water availability close to rock escarpments. Escarpment vegetation, therefore, is higher in species richness and plant productivity than the surrounding forested habitat. These species-rich habitats provide a greater variety of potential foods for herbivores. The impact of rock escarpments on vegetation in the seasonally dry tropics, rather than the existence of more opportunities for speciation via genetic isolation, is likely to have been instrumental in the evolution of the often regionally endemic rock faunas of Australia's dry tropics. -from Authors

dc:title: Fruit and consumer differences in three species of trees shared by Trinidad and Tobago
dc:creator: Keeler-Wolf T.
dc:description: Three species of trees in the premontane forests of both Trinidad and Tobago have a different coterie of fruit and seed consumers on each island. On Trinidad, legitimate dispersers comprising principally frugivorous passerines were most abundant; on Tobago seed-predacious parrots and chachalacas predominated. Significant morphological differences in the fruits of the 2 plant species reflected the difference in consumers. Such characters as relatively thickened fruit walls, a higher frequency of multiple seeds and arils, and enlarged seeds were present in the Tobago populations, which were heavily preyed upon. The Tobago populations also had certain attractive features to legitimate dispersers, such as quantity of fruit pulp, red color of fruit linings, and concentrations of sugar reduced or in lower frequency. The continued survival and reproduction of the Tobago tree populations, despite different dispersal than on Trinidad, is attributed to their protective adaptations and the different habitats on the 2 islands. Under strong isolation, adaptation to a new consumer situation has been selected. -from Author

dc:title: Ecological characterization of a Costa Rican dry forest caterpillar fauna
dc:creator: Janzen D.
dc:description: The dry forests of Santa Rosa National Park range from deciduous and 2m tall to nearly evergreen and 30m tall. This vegetation and a complex mosaic of secondary succession of old fields and pastures supports at least 3140 species of caterpillars. Butterfly caterpillars constitute only 11% of the species and <1% of the biomass. Although moth caterpillars are very species-rich, each of the 725 species of vascular plants is attacked by <20 species of caterpillars. From the viewpoint of a species of plant, the caterpillar species richness in Santa Rosa is much less than from the viewpoint of any of a number of extratropical tree species; they are fed on by many more species of caterpillars at a single location. Although Santa Rosa does have caterpillars that feed on seeds, dung, detritus, bark, etc ↔95% of species eat green leaves. Of these, 37% feed exposed on the leaf surface. A Santa Rossa woody plant loses 1-20% of its leaf area to defoliators during the first half of the rainly season and very little after that; on rare occasions plants are totally defoliated, almost always by a single generation of 1-2 species of caterpillars feeding on their 1-2 sole host plants. Nearly all species of Santa Rosa plants are not fed on by any given species of caterpillar either because the plants contain chemicals that render them unacceptable or because the caterpillar refuses to eat foliage that lacks a feeding stimulant. The negative impacts of inclement weather and carnivores prevent any given species of caterpillar from usually defoliating the few species of plants that it can eat. The Santa Rosa carnivore fauna ranges from absolutely monophagous to highly polyphagous, Its caterpillar food supply fluctuates enormously with year, season, position in a season, and microsite. Virtually all Santa Rosa caterpillar species share their host plants with <20 other caterpillar species. Direct competitive interactions are rare (if they occur at all) owing to the generally low density of caterpillars. -from Author

dc:title: Physiological and growth responses to flooding of seedlings of Hevea brasiliensis
dc:creator: Gomes A.
dc:description: Flooding of soil for 12 wk induced leaf epinasty, reduced chlorophyll content, accelerated ethylene production, inhibited growth, induced decay of roots, and stimulated production of hypertrophied lenticels and adventitious roots on 46-d-old Hevea brasiliensis seedlings. Marked variations were shown among 3 families of Hevea in response to flooding. -from Authors

dc:title: The use of olfaction in food location by frugivorous bats
dc:creator: Rieger J.
dc:description: Fourteen species of bat were caught in baited nets at Corcovado National Park, Puntarenas Province, Costa Rica, though statistical analysis was possible only for the most frequent species, Artiobeus watsoni (Stenodermatinae). Data support the hypothesis that some frugivorous phyllostomids respond opportunistically to olfactory cues to the location of fruit. Rain reduced this tendency, perhaps by inhibiting release of odour chemicals or by encouraging bats to seek shelter. -P.J.Jarvis

dc:title: Nest site and habitat preferences of Centris bees in the Costa Rican dry forest
dc:creator: Frankie G.
dc:description: Examined 5 tree-hole nesting Centris (Anthophoridae) at the Lomas Barbudal Biological Reserve, Costa Rican dry forest. C. bicornuta, C. vittata and possibly C. trigonoides had an overall preference for the more shaded riparian and/or mesic forests. C. bicornuta also showed some preference for oak forests. C. nitida had a clear preference for this habitat. C. analis had no obvious preference for particular habitats. Three Centris species had a strong preference for shaded sites and an 8 mm nest hole diameter; no preference was indicated for height above ground level. Temperatures around 40°C were lethal to early instar bee larvae. Shaded habitats had more optimal temperatures for Centris development. The preferred shaded habitats, riparian and mesic forests, accounted for only c13% of the total land area at Lomas Barbudal. -from Authors

dc:title: The nesting association of the social wasps Mischocyttarus immarginatus and Polybia spp. in Costa Rica
dc:creator: Starr C.
dc:description: The relatively docile Mischocyttarus immarginatus may associate with the more numerous and aggressive Polybia species because the latter afford protection against predatory birds. Data from Santa Rosa National Park, Guanacaste Province, provided less support for this hypothesis than expected, possibly because observations in February-March preceded the breeding season for birds. -P.J.Jarvis

dc:title: Buttress arrangement in Pterocarpus officinalis (Fabaceae): effects of crown asymmetry and wind
dc:creator: Lewis A.R.
dc:description: Buttresses are distributed independently of compass direction in Pterocarpus officinalis at a site in W Puerto Rico where prevailing winds blow out of the E-NE. Buttress length is associated with same-side crown radius. Results contradict findings in studies of other species of trees where buttresses point into the wind and are presumed to function as tension members. External stresses seem not to contribute significantly to development of buttresses in this species. P. officinalis grows in deep mud, and buttresses provide a broad platform that appears to minimize toppling. -from Author

dc:title: Patterns of ant and herbivore activity on five understory euphorbiaceous saplings in submontane Papua New Guinea
dc:creator: Whalen M.A.
dc:description: Examined euphorbiaceous saplings (Macaranga aleuritoides, M. punctata, M. quadriglandulosa, Mallotus philippensis, Homalanthus novo-guineensis) during the wet season in a submontane tropical rain forest. All of these species have foliar extrafloral nectaries. Abundance, density, and composition of the ant and herbivore communities differed among the tree species; ant densities per unit leaf area varied by a factor of c20; and herbivore densities varied by a factor of c3. Leaves of these species were visited by 6-13 species of ants. Ants were experimentally excluded from branches or small saplings of M. aleuritoides, M. punctata and H. novo-guineensis. Numbers of herbivores and levels of leaf damage were significantly greater on ant exclusion saplings than on ant access saplings for M. aleuritoides, but not for the other two species. M. aleuritoides was visited by more ant species than the other 4 tree species and had the highest number of ants per leaf. The ant-plant associations examined are relatively unspecialized compared with most of the ant associations with euphorbs in the Indo-Malesian tropics. -from Authors

dc:title: Age-size relationships and growth behavior of the palm Welfia georgii
dc:creator: Lieberman M.
dc:description: For the arborescent geonomoid Welfia georgii growing in tropical wet forest at La Selva, Costa Rica, height increments over 10 yr period range from 0.3-9.9 m, with a modal value of 2-3 m/10 yr. Number of years needed to attain the maximum height of 20 m from an initial height of 2.3 m ranges from 31 at the fastest growth rate to 80 at the slowest. Median value is 68 yr. Welfia appear to grow more or less continuously once they have reached 2.3 m. The species tolerates a considerable range of light regimes. -from Authors

dc:title: Female reproductive cycles of five species of snakes (Reptilia: Colubridae) from the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico
dc:creator: Censky E.
dc:description: Leptophis mexicanus and Oxybelis aeneus reproduce annually during the rainy season (March-October and March-August, respectively). Dryadophis melanolomus also reproduces during the rainy season, but has a biennial cycle. Stenorrhina freminvillii lays 2 clutches of eggs annually during the dry season (November-April). Elaphe triaspis appears to have aseasonal (continuous) reproduction. Clutch size varies from a mean of 3.1 eggs (D. melanolomus) to 11.6 eggs (S. freminvillii). -from Authors

dc:title: Cecropia peltata, an introduced Neotropical pioneer tree, is replacing Musanga cecropioides in Southwestern Cameroon
dc:creator: McKey D.
dc:description: Cecropia peltata (Moraceae), a fast growing pioneer tree, was introduced into the area around Mt Cameroon near the turn of the century, and has spread primarily in large areas of disturbed vegetation along roads in the Southwest and Littoral Provinces. This spread results in virtual exclusion of its close ecological analogue Musanga cecropoides. -P.J.Jarvis

dc:title: Food habits of piranhas in the low llanos of Venezuela
dc:creator: Nico L.
dc:description: The 8 piranha species (Characidae: Serrasalminae) which coexist in streams and pools of the W Orinoco River Basin Ilanos differ in adult size, body form, and relative abundance. Small juveniles of the abundant and widespread Pygocentrus notatus eat microcrustaceans and aquatic insects. Above 40mm SL, they take small fish and chunks of fish flesh. Small juveniles (20-80mm SL) of Serrasalmus altuvei, S. irritans, S. cf. elongatus, S. rhombeus, S. caribe and Pristobrycon cf. striolatus specialize in fins of other small fishes, but by 80mm SL their diets shift to small fish, pieces of fish flesh, and fins. All sizes of Catoprion mento eat scales. Considerable diet overlap among different piranha species in the same size classes suggests that plentiful food resources are not limiting. -from Authors

dc:title: Natural mortality of Vochysia thyrsoidea in an unburnt Cerrado ecosystem near Brasilia
dc:creator: Hay J.
dc:description: Mean mortality per year was 1.97, but the annual rate varied between 0.64-4.30%. Mortality rate increased with increasing diameter class. Most individuals died standing (67%), probably from insect and fungus attack; other causes of death were windthrow (15%) and lightning (18%). -from Authors

dc:title: Species richness and density of palms in terra firme forests of Amazonia
dc:creator: Kahn F.
dc:description: The characteristics of the palm community in Amazonian terra firme forests are defined from inventories carried out in the lower Tocantins (east), the lower Rio Negro (center), and the lower Ucayali (west) valleys. Most of the palms are small, understory species; the palm community is mainly <10 m in height, and adult arborescent palms occur at very low densities. Species richness and diversity are higher in the W and C forests. -from Authors

dc:title: Visits of Caluromys lanatus (Didelphidae) to flowers of Pseudobombax tomentosum (Bombacaceae): a probable case of pollination by marsupials in central Brazil
dc:creator: Gribel R.
dc:description: Reports on visits by Caluromys lanatus to flowers of Pseudobombax tomentosum in the Federal District of Central Brazil. -from Author

dc:title: The ecology and behavior of the mangrove periwinkle, Littorina angulifera
dc:creator: Gutierrez P.
dc:description: Observations were conducted in mangrove forest at Galeta Point on the Caribbean coast of Panama. The principal component of this forest is the red mangrove Rhizophora mangle which occupies a wide coastal fringe. Line transects were used to determine the distribution and abundance of periwinkles. A population on a single mangrove tree was monitored for >12wk to determine patterns of vertical distribution. -from Author
